As amended, considered; to be read the Third time.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — TRADE AND COMMERCE

speech.p:
asked the President of the Board of Trade (1) the average value per ton of home-grown barley exported since 1st August, 1955;
(2) the average value per ton of barley imported since August, 1955.

speech.speakername: The President of the Board of Trade (Mr. Peter Thorneycroft)
speech.p: The average values are £25 18s. f.o.b. for exports and £24 6s. c.i.f. for imports in the period August, 1955, to May, 1956.

In view of the fact that most of the home barley is sold on the farm at £22 a ton and is subject to subsidy, may I ask whether it is good business to subsidise home-grown barley for export? Would it not be better to store it rather than import more?
Any qusetion about agricultural subsidies should be addressed to my right hon. Friend the Minister of Agriculture.
asked the President of the Board of Trade what raw material imports from European countries are still restricted by quota.
Pulp and paper making materials and leather.

In view of the fact that most European countries have now liberalised to 100 per cent. on raw materials, and even France has done so to 96 per cent., is it not entirely deplorable that this country has liberalised only to just over 80 per cent.?

I do not think it is deplorable. I think our record in liberalisation in Europe has been a good one. These quota restrictions have been imposed for balance of payments reasons, and are, of course, reviewed from time to time.
asked the President of the Board of Trade what steps he is taking to seek the removal of obstacles to British motor car exports in oversea markets.

Many countries admit British cars without restrictions. In recent negotiations with countries which do impose quota restrictions we have secured increased quotas for our motor cars from Finland, France, Italy, and Norway. Tariff concessions for our motor cars were also obtained at the recent G.A.T.T. tariff negotiations in Geneva.

In the case of Australia, which has recently made import quota cuts on motor cars, can the President say whether he has represented to the Australian Government that this cut should be less heavy on sterling motor cars than on dollar ones?
The whole question of our trade relations with Australia is under discussion at present. I would not propose to embark on aspects of it in detailed answers to questions.
But cannot the right hon. Gentleman say at least whether he has made representations on that matter which would be a help to Commonwealth trade as well as to the British motor car industry?
No; I do not propose to embark on any discussion of negotiations which are still in progress.

publicwhip.minor-heading: Indian and Hong Kong Rayon Goods (Duty)

speech.p: asked the President of the Board of Trade what quotas, tariffs or other defences are imposed by the United Kingdom against rayon, rayon goods or other man-made fibres coming from India or Hong Kong.

Imports of Indian or Hong Kong goods containing rayon or other man-made fibres are, in general, liable to duty at five-sixths of the full rates of the silk and artificial silk duties. No quotas or other restrictions are imposed on these imports.

As there is a tariff on Indian and Hong Kong rayon textiles, why is it that whenever we ask for protection for cotton goods we are told that it will provoke an unprecedented breach in the principle of free imports for Empire goods into this country?

Because these silk and rayon duties were Revenue duties, which are in the same category as the McKenna duties. If my hon. Friend would like to discuss the historical origin of these duties with me, I shall be happy to do so at any time.

asked the President of the Board of Trade if he is aware that Australian import quotas for wool cloth from Great Britain for the third quarter of this year are to be reduced; and what alternative proposals he has for maintaining the level of exports in wool cloth which are essential to the woollen textile trade.
The wool textile industry has already shown great resili-

tr.td: Woollen and worsted yarns and woven fabrics
Figures for 1950 are not available on a comparable basis with those for later years.
It is not practicable at this stage to estimate the figure for 1956. A simple projection of the rate for the first five months would not be realistic.

speech.p: ence in the face of changing conditions in its overseas markets. All the services of my Department are available to assist the industry in the further developments of its exports.

Is the President aware that great concern is being felt now since the Australian Government announced the reduction in their quota for woollen textiles for the third quarter of the year, and will he please look further into this matter, so that we can escape the failure that we have had in the cotton and motor car industries?

Yes, I am aware of the damaging nature of the Australian cut, though fortunately, in this case, Australia is one of the smaller markets for wool cloth. Out of the total exports of about £68 million only £1·32 million go into that market.
asked the President of the Board of Trade the figures of woollen textiles exported to Czechoslovakia in the years 1950, 1951, 1952, 1953, 1954, 1955, and the estimated figure for 1956.
As the Answer contains a number of figures, I will, with permission, circulate it in the OFFICIAL REPORT.
In view of the desire of the woollen textile manufacturers to do additional trade with Czechoslovakia, will the right hon. Gentleman do what he can to bring it about?
I will certainly endeavour to promote trade in any area where it seems appropriate to do so.

asked the President of the Board of Trade what the quota of exports of wollen textiles will be in value to Australia for the third quarter of this year compared with the March and June quarters of 1956.

On the basis of past trade, it is estimated that licences to the value of about £170,000 might be used in the present quarter, representing a reduction of about 25 per cent. on the level of the two previous quarters.
asked the President of the Board of Trade if he will make a statement about the first meeting of the International Tin Council held in London.

The first meeting of the Council last week was mainly concerned with matters of internal organisation. The Council, however, considered the expected position of the world tin industry and concluded that estimates of supply and demand indicated an approximate balance during 1956. The Council also fixed 15th September as the date upon which initial contributions from producing countries to the buffer stock of tin and cash should become due. The producing countries indicated their intention of making their contributions mainly in cash. The International Tin Agreement provides for the buffer stock to buy and sell tin at certain price levels in order to stabilise the price.
In welcoming the President's statement, might I encourage him to continue this kind of work, which was promoted by the Labour Government?
asked the President of the Board of Trade if he will make a statement about the visit to the United Kingdom of the Soviet trade mission.

A delegation of Russian experts led by Mr. Malyshev, a Deputy-Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the U.S.S.R. has now arrived in this country. I have already had a useful exchange of views with Mr. Malyshev about the Soviet purchasing programme submitted during the visit of
Mr. Bulganin and Mr. Khrushchev. We are arranging a programme of visits to factories, and we shall show Mr. Malyshev that the possibilities are there for a large increase in Soviet purchases of United Kingdom goods.

In welcoming the statement, might I express the hope that the President will continue to keep in close touch with the Soviet trade mission and, at a final meeting, give it a list of all the things that can be obtained in the United Kingdom?
asked the President of the Board of Trade if he will make a statement upon his talks with the Australian Minister of Trade.

No, Sir. As my right hon. Friend the Minister of State said on 10th July in reply to the hon. Member for Sheffield, Park (Mr. Mulley) these discussions are still proceeding and I am not able to make any statement about them at present.

While I recognise that the discussions are continuing, may I ask the President whether he can say that more notice will be taken than in the past of the representations made by the Australians and brought to his attention by me in the House on several occasions during the last two years?

No, Sir: I am not going to be drawn into any comment whatever about the conduct of the negotiations, not even by reference to past representations by the right hon. Gentleman which I cannot at present recollect.

I should be ruled out of order if I tried to list all the things which I have drawn to the right hon. Gentleman's attention, but if he says "No, Sir" the talks are doomed to failure. I hope that he will give serious consideration to the questions which have been posed time and time again by Australian Ministers.
That is scarcely a question.

asked the President of the Board of Trade whether he is aware that there is a growing concern about the
open sale in Leicester, London, and elsewhere, of spring-clip knives, many of which are imported from abroad; and whether he will now take steps to stop these imports.
As I explained to the hon. Member on 28th July last, this problem cannot, in my judgment, be dealt with by a control on imports.

Will the right hon. Gentleman consider, with his colleagues, doing something to prevent such articles coming into the country, particularly because, first, they are extremely dangerous and there has recently been a manslaughter verdict in respect of the use of one of them, and, secondly, it is a waste of our money to import dangerous weapons to be used for no other purpose than attack?
Questions about dangerous weapons and what should or should not be sold in this country are matters for the Home Secretary.

asked the President of the Board of Trade the value of the imports into Britain from Western Germany of pottery figures for the past twelve months; and the value of the quota for British exports to Western Germany of similar articles.

Imports of pottery figures are not separately specified in the United Kingdom Trade Accounts. As regards the second part of the Question, imports of pottery figures into Western Germany are free from quota restriction.

With reference to pottery (imports generally from Western Germany, however, does the President remember that the last time I asked him about them it was apparent that, whereas Germany exported to us more than £1 million worth in six months, we were restricted to about £60,000 per year? If that is the case, will the right hon. Gentleman look into the problem, because the pottery industry in north Staffordshire is now facing very great difficulties?
I will continue to do all I can to assist the pottery industry of north Staffordshire. The imports of pottery figures into Western Germany are, in fact, free from all quota restrictions.
asked the President of the Board of Trade whether he is yet in a position to announce the steps taken to protect Commonwealth bananas from the results of Brazilian currency manipulations.
I have nothing to add to the Answer which I gave to my hon. Friend on 12th June.

While I fully appreciate the complications, may I ask my right hon. Friend whether he will bear in mind that, unless he takes action before the Jamaican harvest season, immense damage will be done? The bananas will rot, and they will rapidly stink, and so will our reputation.

This scarcely affects West Indian bananas, for they are imported all the year round, and, consequently, the matter of the harvest season there scarcely arises. Imports of Brazilian bananas are in marginal quantities, and there is no evidence at the moment that they are increasing.

Was not an arrangement made with the Brazilian Government whereby no further restrictions of this kind would be imposed in return for concessions granted by us, and did not the House approve an Order on that basis? The Brazilians really are not playing the game.

The Brazilian share of the United Kingdom market is small, and has been falling. Unless I can see some evidence that there really is, as a result of these operations, some rise in the Brazilian share, I do not think there is anything about which we need be concerned.

Surely my right hon. Friend will agree that the Brazilians have carried out this currency manipulation simply because their share has fallen, and they want it to rise again at the expense of our own territories?

This is a complicated matter which I shall be happy to discuss with my hon. Friend, but I scarcely think that is right. Brazilian banana exports to this country are such a small proportion of Brazil's banana exports generally that I cannot think that would have been the chief preoccupation of the Brazilians.

asked the President of the Board of Trade if he is aware of the serious effect the ending of "Add To" and other furniture hire-purchase arrangements is having on working-class households who previously, after repaying part of their obligations, bought more goods to that value, and also on furniture workers in Manchaster and Salford and other centres, who are suffering unemployment and short time; and if he will now reconsider this measure.
I have nothing to add to the reply which I gave to the hon. Member for Shoreditch and Finsbury (Mr. Collins) on 19th April.

Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that the National Union of Furniture Trade Operatives reports a sudden worsening of the situation in the last fortnight? Can he explain how short-time working and unemployment for thousands of first-class craftsmen, whose skill cannot be used in the export trade, and many of whom are elderly and have spent a lifetime in the job, can possibly help the country?

The hon. Gentleman raises in his question some rather wide points which were dealt with very fully in a recent economic debate. I cannot at this stage say on behalf of the Government that we are prepared to relax our general credit policy.

In view of the very special distress caused in the furniture industry by the Government's policy, will the President, even if he cannot promise action now, undertake to watch the situation very carefully in the next few weeks?
I will certainly watch the situation in all industries, and not only in the furniture industry.

asked the President of the Board of Trade if he is aware of the new consequence of the credit squeeze in the furniture industry in that the re-upholstery scheme, which asks for no deposit and so much a week, among other things, is jeopardising the British Standards Institution standards of cleanliness of materials; and if he will therefore amend his regulations to remedy this.
No, Sir.

Does the Minister remember that in 1952, when they ended the Utility scheme, the Government placed confidence in the industry to maintain standards of quality, whereas the credit squeeze is, in the view of the union, so encouraging unscrupulous manufacturers that all the standards of cleanliness which the union has fought for so long to maintain are being undermined?

I cannot agree that we should extend the operations of the credit squeeze into the sphere where people are merely having their own furniture re-upholstered. That does not seem to be a reasonable thing to do.
asked the President of the Board of Trade if he will make the figures of potato imports available privately, on a weekly basis, to the Potato Marketing Board.

Such information as is available to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food about imports of potatoes under open individual licences is already passed weekly to the Potato Marketing Board; further details of arrivals and expected arrivals based on information from the trade are published weekly in various trade publications.

But is the Minister aware that figures of imports which are a month old are utterly useless to the Board in giving growers any reliable advice about lifting, and thereby having orderly marketing? If the right hon. Gentleman cannot give the figures I have asked for, will he at least give the figures of the weekly clearings by the Customs, because that would at least show the trend of imports? It is quite an important matter.

I will look at the last point made by the hon. Member, which is a new one to me and might more appropriately be put to the Chancellor of the Exchequer. All the figures that are available are given to the Potato Marketing Board by the appropriate Ministry.
asked the President of the Board of Trade whether he will make a statement on the problem of the future policy for the film industry.
I am not yet in a position to make a statement.

Having said more than five months ago that he was consulting various sections of the industry, will the Minister hasten a decision in the matter before our film industry fades out altogether? It is in a sorry plight at the moment.
I do not think that our film industry will fade out altogether, and it is important that I should complete my consultations with its various sections.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — NATIONAL FINANCE

speech.p: asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer the average lapse of time between the submission to the Treasury of a hospital capital scheme of £30,000 or over for approval and his giving his decision.

speech.speakername: The Financial Secretary to the Treasury (Mr. Henry Brooke)
speech.p: Between two and three weeks.

Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that in certain instances the lapse of time is considerably longer than this, and runs into many months? Would he give an assurance that this arrangement, which should surely be terminated shortly, will not be used for the purposes of delay, and as a hidden way of cutting down capital expenditure on the hospital services?

There is no intention of that kind at all. In fact, for more than three-quarters of the schemes the average time is no more than nine days, and the average is brought up to two and three weeks by certain schemes which require longer consideration.
asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer his estimate of the amount of Purchase Tax that has been paid on the wool cloth which is now in the hands of tailors.
I have no means of making such an estimate.

May I ask the right hon. Gentleman, if he does not know the figure and will not venture to make an estimate, how he came to tell me last week that it is the problem of the small tailor which makes it necessary to retain the tax on wool cloth? Do the Government not wish to investigate this matter further? Have they no desire to remove Purchase Tax on wool cloth, or are they resolved to continue this unjust discrimination against wool textiles?

This general question has been debated in the House recently. I cannot give the hon. Gentleman an answer to his Question today because I do not know how many times a year, on the average, tailors turn over their stocks.

Is the Minister aware that there is strong feeling in Yorkshire about the discrimination as between wool cloth and cotton textiles in respect of Purchase Tax? Will he give further consideration to the recommendations that have been made to him for the removal of this tax on wool cloth?

This matter has been examined by the Chancellor of the Exchequer personally, and because of the special problem of the small tailors we do not see how it would be practicable to treat wool cloth in the same way as cotton textiles are treated.

asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer the yearly changes in the Treasury's general consumers' index, indicating the drop in the value of the £ sterling on the basis of the year 1945 being 100, to the year 1956; and if he will also show the yearly changes in the general retail prices corresponding with the variations in the value of the £ sterling for the same dates.

speech.speakername: The Economic Secretary to the Treasury (Sir Edward Boyle)
speech.p: As the reply contains a number of figures I will, with permission, circulate it in the OFFICIAL REPORT.

Corresponding value of the £ derived from col. (3) (a)

(b) The Consumer Price Index has been revised for the years from 1946 onwards, so that the figures for 1945 are not strictly comparable with the rest of the series.
